text:
Welcome to How To Cook That, I'm Ann
Reardon. Now lots of people in the

comments have been saying things to the
effect of: she's the Bob Ross of baking! Now, I

didn't even know who Bob Ross was so I
had to go watch some of his videos and

then Ethan and James asked could I follow
a Bob Ross oil painting tutorial but use

the ganache paints like I did for the
Starry Night video many years ago? In

Starry Night I actually piped it on I
didn't use brushes but I can try...

so first let's mix the Bob Ross colors,
he has titanium white and I've made a

big bowl of white chocolate ganache
which is just cream and white chocolate

but as you know white chocolate is
actually not white and even if I add lots

of white food coloring and I mean lots
of it ... we still end up with a creamy

white but it's the best I can do so our
painting will just have to have a

slightly warmer glow to it. Next is
Prussian Blue which according to what I

could see online is a super dark blue,
crimson, sap green. Now if you want to

make this cake I'll list all the food
colors that I use to mix these colors

out of ganache on my HowToCookThat.net
website and the ganache recipe will be

there for you too. The tools Bob uses to
paint are a 1 inch and a 2 inch brush a

fan-shaped brush and a couple of palette
knives and of course a huge paint

palette. Now I couldn't find one this big
so I actually made my own out of wood

using a router so now I have a paint
palette. Speaking of making things

today's video is sponsored by
Squarespace an online platform where you

can make your own website or online
store, more about that later. As well as

the palette we are of course going to
need a canvas ... this is not an ordinary

canvas this is a board which Ihave
screwed supports into because I'm going

to make this canvas out of cake! So we
need some supports going across the cake

so it doesn't just squash down to the
bottom under the weight of

itself. So cover that in foil and stack
up four trays of cake with buttercream

in between the layers and then cover
that in a thin layer of buttercream and

then add a layer of white chocolate
ganache. Now I'm making this cake in the

same size that Bob Ross does his
paintings. "Standard 18 by 24 inch canvas

up here". Once it is all covered in
ganache lay it flat on the bench and

then cover it with a layer of white
fondant. Smooth that out. We want this

nice and flat so there are no bumps that
catch the ganache when we try and paint

so we don't ruin the picture. To make
sharp corners on any cake you just use

two smoothers and you push one into the
other at the corner and you keep doing

that and it kind of just pushes that
fondant or squeezes it together to get a

sharper edge. See how much sharper that
corner is compared to this rounded bit

and the more you do it the sharper it
gets. Put the cake back on the stand and

we are ready to do a fantastic little
edible chocolate ganache painting on a

cake! The bob ross tutorial that I'm
going to follow today is called Mighty

Mountain Lake from season 16 episode 12.
In all his tutorials he starts by

covering the whole canvas in a thin
layer of white paint,

now I'm not sure how that's going to
work with fondant and ganache it may

just make the fondant sticky but I'm
gonna try and follow the tutorial as

best as I can so I've made the gnache
more liquid by warming it slightly and

adding a little bit more cream to it and
now I'm just adding a layer across the

whole cake trying to get it as even as
possible. "Let's just drop in a happy

little sky let's just do it let's just
do a fun painting today start at the

very top of the canvas working all the
way across making little X's little

crisscross strokes." Okay let's put some
Prussian blue on the two-inch brush,

little crisscross strokes. His blends
really nicely with the white paint he

has underneath and kind of
fades into it I'm not sure if ganache

will do that but we'll give it a go. It's
actually blending a whole lot better

than I thought that it would. We have
that nice gradient to the sky what's

next? "So maybe the water lives in our
world, oh I'm not sure where it's gonna

be." I love how he just seems to paint
with no idea of where it's gonna end up.

I always like to have an idea of what
the finished cake is gonna look like

before I start not just make it up as I
go along. Oh look I've got a bit of a

dent in my fondant there just like I was
saying I didn't want. A canvas would be

much easier to paint on than a cake is!
"Let's make some big old fluffy clouds

that live up here in the sky". Some big
old fluffy clouds in the sky. I must

admit I'm having trouble getting the
white ganache to stick onto the blue sky

wet-on-wet isn't really working very
well for ganache at all. I might need to

do it a little bit thicker than he did
and then try and blend it in a bit

without wiping it all off. "Don't overwork
them now, lift them give him a little

fluff." Giving ganache a little fluff
doesn't seem to be doing anything it's

kind of set in place and it's not moving
for anyone. You've obviously got to be a

lot quicker working with ganache than
you do with oil paints. His clouds look

much better than mine do but that's okay
what's next? "Where is your mountain gonna

live? Maybe in our world there it is
comes right down here wherever you

want." The ganache is not sticking to

I can't push the paint right in there

where it's gonna make a dent or a hole
in the fondant on my cake it's not gonna

work I've got to be gentle. I think I'm
gonna have to go thicker like I did

with the clouds. That's better.
Thicker layer of ganache keep that in

mind it spreads a lot better than a thin
one. Did you know that Bob Ross was once an

Air Force Master Sergeant. He said he was
the guy who had to scream at people and

be a mean and tough person.
It's a bit hard to imagine now you see his

paintings. He did promise himself if he
ever got away from it he wasn't going to

be that person anymore. So I think we can
learn something from his life not just

how to paint but if you're stuck in a
job that you don't like do your best

while you're there ... he was promoted to
Master Sergeant and he was there for

twenty years, so he must have done a good
job while he was there but at the same

time don't give up on your dreams. He
painted in his spare time. Nowadays with

the internet you can actually start a
second business or a creative venture on

the side in your spare time.
Squarespace can help you get started

they have pre-designed modern website
templates and you can customize the

layout and the fonts and the colors to
make it look just how you want and then

get right on to creating, blogging,
sharing photos, videos, selling products

whatever your dream is. You can go to
Squarespace.com for a free trial or
squarespace.com/howtocookthat for 10% off your first domain or

website purchase so you can get started
doing the other thing that you really

want to do. I've dipped my brush into a
bowl of hot cream and that seems to be

helping to make the ganache a bit more
brushable. It seems to be blending a lot

better than it was before. "Now then let's
go up here get our little roll of paint

on the small knife and let's begin

definitely doesn't spread as easily as

or if you really are too scared to do it

They can

effectively decorate their own cake,

added a couple of extra screws to

that it doesn't fall down. Imagine if it
slid down and the cake went splat onto

that was a 'happy little accident' would

be a dog. "If you want to have a glacier
maybe I'll tell you one maybe he lives

right along there. Make a decision drop
him and just letting just let him lay in

there and sleep there." I actually haven't

school. The ganache worked fairly well
with the palette knife it of course

doesn't look as amazing as his does but

again this picture might go downhill

quickly from here just you've been

inch brush, I'm just tapping, just tapping I
want to create a little mist down here

at the base of this little mountain big
mountain." It's supposed to look like a

fine mist
not quite what we have. Now for some

happy little trees using the fan brush.
Again I've hated this ganache up whoops

a little bit too runny, it's dripping
down there. This is supposed to be a row of

trees. Now if I paint with the top of the
brush no ganache is transferring to the

cake but if I do it sideways some is
going on but the trees are a bit bent so

we've like got a forest with a strong
wind blowing. You can't expect it to be

perfect out of chocolate you can just do
your best and then just keep going

especially for anything with the brushes
you have to gently build it up otherwise

it doesn't stick and it takes it back to
just the blue fondant. So just very

gently, gently dab on with plenty of
ganache on the brush. Now wash the brush

in hot cream dry out off a little bit on
paper towel

and gently pull down to blur the
reflection on the water. Then very gently

brush across to blur it a little I'm not
happy with that big splotch that I

dropped down on the water there so I'm
gonna try and get that bit off which it

seems to be coming off for me. Pull down
their reflections a little more and then

add some fall colors along the base of
the trees for the leaves that have

dropped down off the trees there. Now the
brush is not working for me very well so

I'm gonna swap back to the palette knife
and just kind of squash on some ganache

and pull it up and now it kind of looks
like they're flames ... let's add a little

bit of green and blend that in and so it
doesn't look like a forest is on fire!

And now I'm going to swap to a piping
bag for this I just can't do it with a

brush we're supposed to add a line of

under that's where the land is where the
land meets the water and I just can't

it's not working but I know I can do it

knife again because you're doing
actually want a perfect line there just

a little bit of reflection on the water.
Then a little bit of land right in the

foreground of the picture in front of
the water there. I've heated this ganache

again with a little bit of extra cream
to thin it down. The problem I'm having

is it's just not giving good coverage
like you get with paint so you can see

can still see blue through it where is
it either dark color with paint and you

can't see anything through it. I'll add
some Indian yellow over the top and

painting with a palette knife and piping
bag definitely suits ganache but the

brushwork not so much. Well it's
definitely nowhere near as good as a Bob

Ross landscape painting but considering
that I haven't painted a landscape since

high school and it's not a canvas and
it's not paint, I think it turned out

okay! What do you think? I always get

the cakes once we've made them? I'm
actually going to cut this one up into

six portions and drop it over to some
neighbors and

friends. Most people are more than happy
